summary: This is an FBI communication regarding the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager. It details how Rodriguez possessed and attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for underage victims from multiple jurisdictions, including California. The document requests copies of driver's licenses for two individuals from California.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an FBI obstruction of justice investigation for retaining and attempting to sell an address book containing names and phone numbers believed to be of underage girls, which he obtained while working for Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Former subject of a child prostitution investigation; his former employee, Rodriguez, possessed an address book with potential victim information. Epstein pled guilty to lesser offenses via a non-prosecution agreement.

connections.description: Rodriguez was a house manager and butler for Epstein during his employment in 2005.
Rodriguez retained evidence (an address book) related to Epstein's alleged crimes and attempted to sell it, obstructing the investigation into Epstein.

events.title: Start of Epstein Child Prostitution Investigation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein became the subject of a child prostitution investigation.

events.title: Rodriguez Employment with Epstein Ends
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez's employment with Jeffrey Epstein ended; he retained an address book with names and phone numbers believed to be of underage girls.

events.title: FBI Opens Obstruction Case Against Rodriguez
events.description: The Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Rodriguez Attempts to Sell Address Book
events.description: Rodriguez attempted to sell the address book to an undercover employee (UCE) posing as an employee of a plaintiff's attorney suing Epstein.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, was investigated for obstruction of justice for possessing and attempting to sell an address book with names/numbers of potential underage victims.
The address book was believed to contain underage victims from jurisdictions outside the Southern District of Florida, which was the scope of Epstein's non-prosecution agreement.
Rodriguez stated that Epstein would have girls flown into Palm Beach from various locations, and the address book had a section labeled 'California Massage'.
The FBI was seeking copies of driver's licenses for two individuals (names redacted) from the San Diego and Los Angeles areas, believed to be connected to the address book.
Epstein's non-prosecution agreement and guilty plea in Florida state court were limited to victims identified in the Southern District of Florida, suggesting potential undisclosed victims elsewhere.
